sub.title: Adult Dosing
sub.mono: Ovarian cancer, Persistent or recurrent disease; monotherapy as second-line after cisplatin or alkylating agent-based combination: 260 mg/m(2)/day ORALLY in 4 divided doses (after meals and at bedtime) for 14 or 21 consecutive days per 28 day cycle

sub.title: Pediatric Dosing
sub.mono: safety and effectiveness in children have not been established

sub.title: Dose Adjustments
sub.mono:
• gastrointestinal intolerance: (unresponsive to symptomatic measures) temporarily discontinue for 14 days or longer; restart at 200 mg/m(2)/day
  • myelosuppression: (WBC count less than 2,000/mm(3), granulocyte count less than 1,000/mm(3), OR platelet count less than 75,000/mm(3)) temporarily discontinue for 14 days or longer; restart at 200 mg/m(2)/day
  • neurotoxicity, progressive: temporarily discontinue for 14 days or longer; restart at 200 mg/m(2)/day; discontinue indefinitely if neurologic symptoms do not stabilize

sub.title: Indications
sub.mono:
FDA-Labeled Indications
Ovarian cancer, Persistent or recurrent disease; monotherapy as second-line after cisplatin or alkylating agent-based combination
Non-FDA Labeled Indications
  • Breast cancer
  • Colon cancer
  • Endometrial carcinoma
  • Malignant epithelial tumor of ovary
  • Malignant lymphoma
  • Multiple myeloma
  • Small cell carcinoma of lung

mono.title: Black Box Warning
mono.mono:
Oral (Capsule)
Peripheral blood counts should be monitored at least monthly, prior to the initiation of each course of altretamine, and as clinically indicated. Because of the possibility of altretamine-related neurotoxicity, neurologic examination should be performed regularly during altretamine administration.

sub.title: Contraindications
sub.mono:
• hypersensitivity to altretamine
  • preexisting severe bone marrow depression or severe neurologic toxicity

sub.title: Precautions
sub.mono:
• concurrent administration of MAO inhibitor class antidepressants; may cause severe orthostatic hypertension
  • concomitant administration of cimetidine not recommended
  • concomitant administration of pyridoxine; adversely affects response duration

sub.title: Breast Feeding
sub.mono: Micromedex: Infant risk cannot be ruled out.

mono.title: Adverse Effects
mono.mono:
Common
  • Endocrine metabolic:Alkaline phosphatase raised (9%)
  • Gastrointestinal:Nausea and vomiting (mild-to-moderate, up to 70%; (Blac, 1980); severe, 1%)
  • Hematologic:Anemia (33%), Leukopenia (5%), Thrombocytopenia (9%)
  • Neurologic:Peripheral nerve disease (up to 31%)
  • Renal:Serum blood urea nitrogen raised (9%), Serum creatinine raised (7% to 20%)
  • Other:Fatigue (7% (grade 3))
Serious
  • Hematologic:Myelosuppression
  • Neurologic:Neurotoxicity, Seizure (1%)

mono.title: Mechanism Of Action
mono.mono: Systemic: The exact mechanism of action is unknown . Although altretamine structurally resembles an alkylating agent, it has not been found to have alkylating activity in vitro . There is some evidence that it may inhibit DNA and RNA synthesis .

mono.title: Administration
mono.mono:
• General Information
    use proper procedures for handling and disposal of chemotherapy
  • Oral
    take doses after meals and at bedtime

mono.title: Monitoring
mono.mono:
• evidence of tumor response
  • peripheral blood counts; at least monthly, prior to initiating each course
  • neurologic examinations; prior to initiating each course
  • signs and symptoms of myelosuppression

sub.title: Clinical Effects
sub.mono:
ALTRETAMINE
OVERDOSE: No data available. ADVERSE EFFECTS: Dose-limiting toxicities include nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, abdominal pain and neuropathy. Dose-related myelosuppression has occurred rarely with therapy.

sub.title: Treatment
sub.mono:
ALTRETAMINE
  • Decontamination: Activated charcoal, gastric lavage.
  • Support: Treatment is symptomatic and supportive.
  • Colony stimulating factor: Filgrastim for severe granulocytopenia: 5 mcg/kg/day IV infusion or subQ
  • Monitoring of patient: Monitor CBC, renal function and hepatic enzymes, electrolytes and fluid status.
  • Pyridoxine: Used to prevent peripheral neuropathy with therapeutic use; no experience in overdose.

sub.title: Range of Toxicity
sub.mono:
ALTRETAMINE
THERAPEUTIC: 260 mg/m(2)/day divided in 4 doses, daily for 14 to 21 days. TOXICITY: Not established.

mono.title: Clinical Teaching
mono.mono:
• This drug may cause diarrhea, nausea, vomiting, or peripheral neuropathy.
  • Instruct patient to report signs/symptoms of neurotoxicity or myelosuppression.
  • Patient should take doses after meals and at bedtime.
  • Advise patient on the proper handling and disposal of chemotherapy drugs.
  • Advise patient to avoid vaccines during therapy due to drug-induced immunosuppression.
  • Avoid concomitant pyridoxine (vitamin B6), cimetidine, and MAO-type antidepressants.
  • Avoid concomitant pyridoxine (vitamin B6), cimetidine, and MAO-type antidepressants.
